ygData.subject: I am new
ygData.msgSnippet: A long, long time ago, when CD-ROM drives still used caddies and DOS was just as much of an acceptable OS as Windows 3.11, I had this disc full of Shareware.

A long, long time ago, when CD-ROM drives still used caddies and DOS 
was just as much of an acceptable OS as Windows 3.11, I had this disc 
full of Shareware. Actually, there was a series of such discs full of 
Shareware, but I forgot what they were called. I discovered that CRPGs 
could be fun, and I also discovered that Abuse was really freaking 
hard.

With my 3'6" height and 386 computer, I played Gladiator. I discovered 
that it was actually pretty fun! Unfortunately, it was Shareware, and 
by now, at least 500 different games of Shareware had tantalized me 
with "REGISTER NOW!" And my dad didn't want to pay for about 500 
different games.

Much later, when I was about 4'6", and a 36.4k connection was the 
fastest around, I discovered FSGames' website. I was like, "OMG ITS 
GLADIATOR" and was overjoyed. But still, they wanted registration. I 
did, however, download and play the Win95 alpha.

I visited FSGames once again with a DSL connection. I now had a credit 
card, so I figured that it wouldn't hurt to spend about $10 on a game 
that I remembered was one of the best games I ever played. By then, I 
was also playing things like Infantry Zone (http://www.infantryzone.
com), Liero, and Starcraft, but that didn't stop me from enjoying such 
an old game. While I was at it, I also looked up the old Excelsior 
Phase One: Lysandia game and the Ultizurk series.

Finally, I ended up deciding to look at http://www.fsgames.com again. 
But the website was gone! I typed +"gladiator" +"forgotten sages" into 
Yahoo and found this mailing list. This was about a few days ago. I've 
also come across the OpenGlad project.

Hello everybody.
